text_answer.content:
Discussions of slavery. Would be fine if there was a chance to have a larger conversation, but that's not what we're here for.
The AI messed up a couple of sentences, making the answers misaligned. Sentence 1 doesn't finish until after 39, since the Matthew v. 38, 39 is a book/verse/line attribution.
I think sentences 23 is correctly done, but it's a weird spot since it's a colon followed by a quote.
relievethemof in line 21.

classifications.name: Specifically focusing on the question and answer choices, is the correct answer obvious to you?
Comments:

text_answer.content:
This is a dense passage. I know the Weighted Average Readability is only 8.9, but there is some rare vocab (indices, witherward, pernicious...), the sentence structures can get super complicated, with grammar that I had to look up to make sure was accurate (I have never seen a comma *and* a dash used together), and it's very stream-of-conciousness. Though the larger book might be accessible to 9th grade (I've never read it, so I don't know), this section is probably closer to 11th or 12th.
Question 1 is... whew. Even if we assume the AI is interpreting the text correctly (which is arguable), no 9th grader is ever going to get the answer in a sentence that complicated. Even elimination doesn't really work since 23 further contextualizes what 22 introduces.
Questions 2 and 8 are functionally the same.
Question 3 applies circular logic and ultimately doesn't have an answer.
Question 7 is correct, but it'll be a tough one.
For question 10, sentence 14 is more detailed regarding the speaker's concerns, but 15 also has a valid argument.

Comments:

text_answer.content:
This feels like it starts in the middle of a quote? There's an end quote after sentence 4, but no open quote.
The AI didn't number the first sentence of paragraph 2, the first two sentences of paragraph 4, the first sentence of paragraph 5. Marking the answer wrong because that's too much effort.
The AI does seem to have figured out titles, though, as Mrs. Allan was fine.
Questions 5 and 7 read strangely since there's a passing of time in the passage.
Theycouldgo in the sentence before 15.

classifications.name: Comments:

text_answer.content:
"Sexual pleasure" in sentence 8. Also sentences 9, 10, 11, 13. The character described in 18/19 and 29 is inappropriate as well.
I think the first sentence isn't supposed to be there? It's the end of a quote and what should be the second sentence isn't numbered.
These should be broken up into paragraphs at sentences  11, 15, 17, 21, 24, 26, 29, and 30 as per the source material.
For question 3, I guess the answer is looking at his reaction as happy or elated, but it's a bit of an inference.
For question 4, sentences 6 and 7 are supported. 8 is when we move past the 'after greeting her' stage.
Questions 7 and 10 refer to the same moment in the story.

So Siddhartha has generally been an issue for this program whener it shows up. Despite how inappropriate this section is, the book itself is generally fine. However, the major issue I've run into is that the quality of the translation isn't great. I've pointed this out a couple of times in the past, but sentence 16 is a great example of what I mean. Grammatically it may make sense to write it that way in the original German (I don't read German, so I don't know), but in English it's a hot mess of a sentence. It's... readable, but only barely. Another translation I found had a period after forests, which makes so much more sense. I don't want to say we should chuck the book entirely, but we should try and get the best translation we can and I don't think the one we have is it.
Susan Bernofsky and Hilda Rosner are said to have the best versions, but I a) haven't read either and can't confirm and b) don't know what the copyright situation is for either work.
